awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research/Research Initiation: What Practice Makes Perfect
awd_abstract_narration:
Practice plays an important role in developing useful abilities for almost any undertaking. Although practice has been studied extensively in competitive sports and musical performance, it is understudied within engineering education. With advancements in training and practice strategies, athletes and musicians have kept setting new records. The gold standard for practice has been discovered as "deliberate practice" which puts great emphasis on practice specificity. To achieve superior performance, elite performers must practice with tailored drills focused on specific skill deficiencies just as how they practiced as beginners to gain rapid progress. In contrast, engineering students rarely practice with such specificity. For example, students usually practice with textbook problems which might exceed their current skill level. Such practice will result in no or little progress and reduced confidence. It is critical to engage students with effective practice to enhance learning efficiency. The proposed study will examine the effectiveness of tailored practice strategies in the gateway engineering mechanics courses (i.e., Statics and Dynamics) which have a high impact on engineering student retention. Special focus will be given to exploring what types of deliberate practice can help students more effectively in the initial learning stage as well as in the later retention phase. Additionally, this research initiation will also investigate practice strategies which benefit engineering faculty in acquiring knowledge and skills for conducting engineering education research. Findings and insights gained from this research will expand the community of engineering education researchers and expedite the adoption of evidence-based instructional strategies.
The study will be conducted at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. The effects of three strategies (i.e., backwards faded practice, modular practice, and spaced practice) on developing and consolidating problem solving skills will be investigated in the gateway courses. Mixed-methods will be used. Multivariate and univariate statistical models will be utilized to analyze data collected from the counterbalanced research design with the benefit of controlling confounding factors. Quantitative data will be collected to analyze learning performance and qualitative data will be used to contextualize quantitative findings as well as refine practice. The intellectual merits of the project are manifested by advancing knowledge of practice design for mechanics courses and beyond, generating information in greater detail about changes to students' conceptual and procedure knowledge of mechanics through practice, as well as providing insights on expanding the engineering education research community. The broad impacts of the project are intrinsic to the research itself because the findings from this project will not only impact 490 undergraduate engineering students and enhance learning mechanics, but also have the potential to improve learning in other applicable science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) areas in which practice serves as a major learning mechanism. With Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University's increasing effort on recruiting women, people with disabilities, and underrepresented minorities in the STEM programs, the project will contribute in diversifying the STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

Collaborative Research/Research Initiation: What Practice Makes Perfect, the NSF-funded research was a collaborative project between Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (#1927284) and University of Central Florida (#1927290). The NSF-supported project aimed to refine the application of practice strategies in engineering education, focusing on foundational mechanics courses. The project introduced a novel framework named Practice for Schema Acquisition and Consolidation (PSAC), inspired by 'deliberate practice' methodologies, to align practice activities with student development stages, thus aiming to bolster learning efficiency and concept retention.

The purposes of the project were:

  1. To develop practice strategies, denoted as PSAC, to increase students’ learning in two fundamental engineering mechanics courses (i.e., Statics and Dynamics).
  2. To develop an engineering professor’s knowledge and skills for conducting research in engineering education through mentorship and collaboration with an educational research methodologist.

The specific objectives of this project were:

  1. Investigating the effectiveness of PSAC on increasing engineering students’ learning.
  2. Assessing the project's impact on preparing the engineering faculty to become engineering education researchers and to share their knowledge with the engineering faculty community.
  3. Understanding the impact of PSAC as perceived by students and instructors.
  4. Assessing PSAC's impact on serving underrepresented students and students with lower performance.

Intellectual Merit

The research underpinning PSAC has enriched our understanding of practice within engineering education. We assessed the efficacy of three tailored practice strategies—backwards faded practice, modular practice, and spaced practice—under the PSAC umbrella, to discern their impact on students' understanding of mechanics.

Design of Practice Problems: Through PSAC, practice problems were crafted using a four-component instructional design model, calibrated to students' learning abilities. This approach mitigated cognitive overload and ensured the appropriateness of challenge levels for effective skill building.

Systematic Task Analysis: Implementing PSAC, the project conducted a detailed task analysis to identify the knowledge and skills gap relative to students' existing competencies. This informed the instructional design in the selection and development of learning tasks, laying a solid foundation for knowledge acquisition.

Mastery Learning: PSAC's application of the mastery learning principle fostered an inclusive learning environment, accommodating students' varying paces of comprehension and ensuring a thorough understanding of concepts before progression.

Educational Technologies: Within the PSAC framework, a variety of educational technologies were adopted to facilitate mastery learning, providing diverse learning supports to meet the needs of different students. Specifically, a custom Generative Pretrained Transformer (GPT), the newly released feature by OpenAI, was implemented to provide students with resources pertinent to their questions.

Broader Impacts

PSAC's broader impacts were significant in several areas:

Enhanced Learning: PSAC was instrumental in enhancing the learning outcomes of over 700 undergraduate engineering students, laying a foundation expected to positively influence their broader STEM education.

Inclusive Education: PSAC's integration of various educational technologies and mastery learning principles has contributed to more equitable educational practices, catering to a wide demographic of students.

Assessment Improvement: Within the PSAC framework, the project focused on refining assessment methodologies, heightening their reliability and validity, and thus providing a more accurate gauge of student learning and performance.

Research Training: The project provided the principal investigator, an engineering faculty member, with a robust platform for educational research training, equipping them with comprehensive skills in quantitative and qualitative research design, data collection, and analytical methods. After this training and practice in educational research, the engineering faculty member has established a foundational understanding of educational research.

Conclusion
The PSAC framework has yielded valuable insights that are poised to inform the enhancement of practice strategies in engineering education. The project's contributions are instrumental to the continuous improvement of STEM education and underscore the necessity for instructional strategies that effectively respond to students' diverse learning requirements. The research conducted paves the way for further investigation into effective teaching methodologies within the engineering education community.
